sp.p: You have hurt me more than I do you.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: You will bruise my arm.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You have bruised my heart.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Me! Who are you?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The Mountebank Belphégor!(throws off his mask and cloak.)

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Heaven!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, no more deceit. Catherine has told me all she knew— that you, in my absence, came like a vile thief, and bore from me my wife—to Bordeaux, was it not? Speak—speak.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: A word, Belphégor—the moments are precious. In one word: make but the least noise or disturbance, you alone will suffer—the disgrace will fall upon yourself.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ask you but one thing—where is she?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: You have seen on your road the proofs of my power—how yon have been chased, hunted, tracked.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: If I but point my finger, it is your destruction: you are cast into a dungeon, dragged before the judgment-seat; and—ere the sun has twice set—shot.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You have not told me where she is?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: H a ! a thought.(aside) All I have told you is but deceit— she is no more the daughter of the Duke than you or I—she pleased me, and I would have borne her off.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Wretch! would you deceive me?(throws him to his feet.)

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Help—help! Enter HERCULES, FLORA, and all the MASQUERADERS, C.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p:
He will strangle him!
BELPHEGOR flourishes a stick or staff which he take from HERCULES.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: He who advances one step, I strike him down—(then to ROLLAC) Where is she?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: At the residence of the Montbazons.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The proof—the proof !

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: (taking from his pocket a small portfolio.) It is here!—my letters—my correspondence.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (snatches it.) Give it me!

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: (aside.) Ha!—you take my letters—my correspondence!— she is lost to you!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (to FLORA.) Mademoiselle, you will in pity guard and protect that boy—I would go alone.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: With my life!

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: (aside.) I am saved!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now, make way—I have done! Farewell, Messieurs! Way for the mountebank!(he bounds through them, off C.)

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: —House of the Duke DE MONTBAZON—A saloon, very richly furnished—A large table, R.—Escrutoire with papers, L. Enter DE COURGEMONT, preceded by SERVANT, C.D.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (C.) Very well; as the Duke is not here, I'll wait for him. (SERVANT bows and exits, C.) The Duke is now in great favour, and I entreated his good offices—(looks off.) The Count de Blangy! What the devil brings him here? An intriguing—plotting—fawning ( D E BLANGY, having entered, comes down, R.) Ah! my dear Count, this is a pleasure; I am delighted to see you.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: The Grand Bailli!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: You surprise me here, in coming to pay my respects to your noble cousin;—not that I am like the rest of the world here only with an interested or ambitious motive—I've not come to ask for anything.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (aside.) The lying hypocrite!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: And you?

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: Me? Oh! I want nothing. Enter the DUKE, the JUDGE D'ARPIGNOL, the COMMANDER of the Pouffieres, C.— The DUKE and the COMMANDER have appeared at the back during these last words, the DUKE having despatches in his hand.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R. by table.) What rapid despatch to my request. Messieurs, here are two despatches, I fancy, concern you.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (eagerly, going to the DUKE.) My appointment!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (the same.) My nomination !—allow me.(they both take their letters.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (to COMMANDER and JUDGE.) Messieurs, the King has been so kind as to compliment me on the recovery of my son's child.(he sits at official table, R.H.)

sp.speaker: R.H.
sp.p: Oh, really!(they are cringing before him.)

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (disappointed.) What's this—substitute to the King's procurer?

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (with joy.) Commissaire extraordinary of the department of the Gironde! I am commissaire extraordinary!(struts across with great importance.) Gentlemen, I receive your compliments(then to C.)

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: Oh ! there's some mistake. It's impossible—the King has been deceived.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: The King's never deceived, Sir—the king is infallible.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (who cast his eye upon the address of his envelope.) But you'll allow me, if you please—this is not my address—'tis not directed to me.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: I have nothing to do with your address.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: But you have with your own;—this is to you.(gives it.)

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Me? (reads the direction to the letter in his own hand.) His own " Castle Blan—Castle Blan"

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: " Castle Blangy." You have got my letter and I have got yours.(laughs.)

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Well, but

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: You are always in such a hurry.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: But am I no more than a wretched substitute?(crossing to L.) It's impossible!—it's absurd!—the King has been imposed upon!

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: The King's never deceived, Sir—the King is infallible.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Eh!(looks foolish—aside.) Insolent intriguer! (goes up in a passion.)

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (C.) Oh! here are my instructions. (reads.) Ah, Heavens! Lavarennes, under the name of Rollac!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: BLANGY.
sp.p: Nothing—duty calls me instantly to the Prefecture— excuse me, cousin, I must bid you adieu for the present. Monsieur the Substitute, I want you—follow me.(goes up to C.D.)

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: What's that you say?

sp.speaker: BLANGY.
sp.p: (with polite authority) Will you follow me ?

sp.speaker: COUR.
DUKE.
sp.p:
(C.) Yes, my good friends, the King is in the best disposition as regards our lost one—so miraculously recovered—he has
restored to us all our rights:—my son's child will inherit title, wealth, and estates.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: ( R . ) But in the midst of this, you will own, Duke, it is necessary to conceal from the King's knowledge, the miserable sphere in which she was found, for the reputation of our family—no one, I hope, knows

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: No one, except yourself, my cousin De Blangy, and the Chevalier Rollac—his letters inform me that he has completely got rid of this wretched man, the husband, and enforced him to sail for America.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: You owe him much for his zeal and devotion in your cause. Enter SERVANT, C.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The Chevalier de Rollac.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Admit him—then the man has safely embarked. Enter BELPHEGOR, C. in a Court suit, powdered wig, white breeches sword, &c. His bearing is rather outre, but not in exaggeration.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (R.C.) Messieurs, allow me to salute you.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R.) I am delighted to see you, Chevalier, you are here at last.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I came as soon as possible believe me—we never met before —but you are the Duke de Montbazon.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (turns to COMMANDER and JUDGE, conversing) You are right, Chevalier.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside, in front) I know I am, by the letters of the villain Rollac, whom I tracked on his way—I struck him down like a dog —secured his pocket book—and am here as himself, his letters have told me of all.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: (L.H.) He has a noble, manly figure.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: (L.C.) He looks the gentleman of a distinguished family.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: Carries his head nobly on his shoulders.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: And his shoulders carry a noble head.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) They are casting me up. If I could see Madeline before they recognise me(looks about anxiously).

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: ( R . ) Chevalier—Monsieur de Rollac.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (starts—comes down R.C.) I beg your pardon

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Permit me to present to you two of the principal members of my family—this gentleman, the Commander of Pouffieres.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Monsieur(bows).

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, I see—you are a Commander of Pouffieres, are you? (crosses to him.)

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: I am, Monsieur, I am proud to say.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: The Judge d'Arpignol, a relative of the ninth Touraines.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (crosses to him, L.C.) Oh, you are of the Tureen family, are you?—then, I suppose, you are first-cousin to the Spoons(they stare.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: You are merry, Chevalier!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Always—bless you! I'm a complete Merry Andrew—we shall have rare sport together.
Enter HERCULES, C

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: ( R . ) Ah, my dear uncle!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Is this one of the spoons?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (stares.) Great uncle!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Silence, this is the Chevalier Rollac—Chevalier, my nephew.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (crosses to him, R.) This is your nephew, eh?—your hand.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (with some pride gives his hand, as BELPHEGOR shakes it. cries out) Oh, oh! I say, great uncle.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: ( goes up while they attend HERCULES, who groans—then comes down.) Duke—You have introduced me to Monsieur Touffier and to Monsieur Rigmarole.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: D'Arpignol.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, didn't I say so? but I don't see my—that is—I don't see the newly-recovered lady.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: You ought to know that it is impossible, at the instant.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How, impossible?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Why, she is there.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There—where?(looks about—HERCULES sits L. H. 1 E . ) D U K E Where you, yourself, instructed De Blangy to take her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, ah!—yes, I recollect.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: And an excellent idea it was.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Capital—wasn't it? I am very inventive; but I shall see her soon?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: What a fidget the Chevalier seems to be in.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Silence, nephew.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yes, great uncle.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (to BELPHEGOR.) You'll pardon me, Chevalier; but you have not informed me of your projects.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Projects!(aside) Now, what the devil projects, had this scoundrel Rollac?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: This vagabond—this mountebank—are we quite clear of him?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) Holloa!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Ha! have you still fear of him ?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What—me fear him? While I am here, Duke, I give you my promise, he'll not appear at your gate.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Thanks for your information.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But this Belphégor JUDGE(laughing) What—is he called Belphegor ?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (aside) What a devilish funny name!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (laughs with the JUDGE) Yes, Belphégor, ha, ha, ha! Yes, he is called Belphégor. Is it not funny, eh? Belphegor!—ha, ha, ha! (JUDGE and HERCULES laugh immoderately.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (to BELPHEGOR) But what is your opinion of this man?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My opinion is that he is not far off.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (surprised) Indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
You know what these fellows are—these mountebanks, they
are so confoundedly clever—so nimble—so light—whichever way you throw them, they are sure to come upon their feet.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: But we will trip him up.(goes up to table, R.H.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But are we not as great rogues as he! Now if this conjuring rascal had introduced himself here, in borrowed plumes, or name, to seek his wife. If he had come as a gentleman, like you or me, with the perpendicular assurance of this gentleman (to COMMANDER —who is L.H.) taking snuff out of his mounted box, dirtying his nose, and soiling his frill—as this(takes snuff from the JUDGE'S box) or pirouetting on his heel, with his hat under his arm, in this fashion—and you had not discovered him to be a vile rascal, then we might have been surprised.(strikes the JUDGE on the belly) Ha, ha, ha! the idea is enough to make one burst with laughter—is it not? (crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: (L. groans) Burst—yes—that's the word.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (sits at table) I see that your visit to America has rendered you somewhat eccentric.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Eh—oh—yes. I know lots of tricks.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: ( R . ) If I am not mistaken, Chevalier, you were at Biberach?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Biberach—me!—Biberach! Who's Biberach? No.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: What, were you not presented to his Majesty on the night of the battle?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, ah—yes, yes.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Oblige us by a description of that great fight.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) How the devil am I to describe a fight!

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: If it's only to oblige me, Chevalier—I think of entering the army.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: With my interest, a post in the Pouffiers.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The whole details?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: No, they will recall too fatal remembrances.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You must know, gentlemen(taking COMMANDER and JUDGE by the arm),} when Grain D'Amour sounded the trumpet for the performance to commence

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (L.) Grain D'Amour ? JUDGE (L.C.) Performance?

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: (R. of B E L . ) A very odd expression for a military man!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: ( C. , aside) Grain D'Amour, the head trumpeter of our legion; and it was a wonderful performance, this Battle of Bib

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: -erach.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Don't interrupt me, if you please. (COMMANDER bows.) Beberawach!

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (to DUKE.) That serves him right. DUKE(at table.) Hold your tongue, fool!

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Yes , uncle.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: As I was saying, it was a wonderful battle—the balls flying about like hail, and the men falling like so many bees. We were sixty thousand strong, and we were ranged to receive the enemy in a circle—that is, in two circles;—the first circle marched on first, and discharged their sixty thousand firelocks loaded with ball.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Sixty thousand men fire at once, in two circles?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The inner circle fired over the others' heads—so, you see, the outer circle balls told there—(hits JUDGE on the stomach, who gets away)—and the inner circle there—(hits COMMANDER on the head, whose hat goes over his eyes). The skirmish then commenced; we marched on the enemy, and the enemy marched on us—they gave way, we gave way—they fired, we fired—they charge, we charge—the cavalry on the infantry, the infantry on the cavalry. The sixty thousand fired again—we were covered with smoke—and nothing else was seen;—that's the way, gentlemen, we gained the victory!(struts about.)

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Victory?

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Victory?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Victory!

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: I always thought it was a defeat.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (returning to C.) Defeat?—who said it was not?

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: You said it was a victory.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I said it was a victory, while we couldn't see ourselves for smoke; but when that cleared away, of course we saw it was a defeat.(goes up.)

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: (aside) A very smoky account, certainly.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: I think I shall decline entering the army at present, there might be a war, and the Pouffieres might be in the first circle.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (comes down) But come, I am anxious to see the lady. The COMMANDER and JUDGE at table. R.H., take a map and seem to explain the battle.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: On the instant(rings).

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That's right. SERVANT enters door, U.E.L.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Conduct the Chevalier to his apartment—she will be here shortly, Chevalier.

sp.speaker: BEL.
DUKE.
sp.p: Our cousin De Blangy has not deceived us in reporting the Chevalier to be rather vulgarised by his American sojourn.

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: I have travelled a very great deal, but it never changed my manners or ideas.(taking snuff, goes up L.H.)

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: As great an ass as ever. Enter SERVANT, R.H. 3 E.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mademoiselle Vermandois, and Madame Madeline. Enter Mademoiselle VERMANDOIS, R. 3 E.

sp.speaker: Madlle. V.
sp.p: Approach niece. Enter MADELINE, R. 3 E. —Now, carry your head high, as the daughter of a Montbazon.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Oh, pray excuse me, but I know that I am unfit to meet such society—I tremble lest—

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (L.C.) Cast aside all fear, my child, you have here a father, with open arms, to receive you—a family, loving and respecting you—nay, do not tremble, we forget all, we love you.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Oh, for this kind assurance, my thanks—my grateful thanks.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (embracing her) Look, gentlemen, see you not the features of her unhappy father; after twenty years exile, I return to find his child, and my title, wealth, estates restored, should I not be joyous, and you, my child, should be happy. You are now in your proper sphere amongst those of birth.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Yet you must know, Monsieur, that I regret the absence of those from whom they have torn me.

sp.speaker: Madlle. V.
sp.p: Have you not quitted them voluntarily, child?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: I have quitted them to save my daughter, Madame.

sp.speaker: Madlle. V.
sp.p: Oh, don't annoy yourself. Your daughter is out of danger now.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: But my husband—it was to plead his cause that I insisted on coming here.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: But, my child, I cannot dream

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Hear me, Duke. The man who has acted in your name has o'erstepped your orders, I am certain.

sp.speaker: Madlle. V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: One moment, Madame, if you please.—(to D U K E ) A female, living in the same house in which we dwelt at Angouleme, was, I fear, induced by him to act as his accomplice. I was enabled on my arrival at Bordeaux, to communicate with her, and from her I learnt that my husband had been subjected to the cruel persecutions of this man, and in the lowest, most abject state of misery and distress, enforced to fly. Oh, Duke, had you instructed him to separate us from each other, you would not, I am sure, cruelly and wantonly have given orders that would inflict severest suffering on him—my husband—and my poor boy.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: No, no, my child—they have deceived you(rings) Enter SERVANT. — Tell the Chevalier Rollac I wait for him.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: The Chevalier Rollac—is he here?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: From himself you can learn the truth. Enter BELPHEGOR, D.L.U.E.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (as he enters) The Duke wants me—eh?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (aside) That voice!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: We shall see the lady, then, I dare say.(sees MADELINE) Ah!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (aside) It is him—my husband!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Present your respects, Chevalier.(goes to table R.U.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (approaching MADELINE, L.C.) More beautiful than ever.

sp.speaker: Madlle. V.
sp.p: Yes, she looks better, of course, than in her mountebank rags.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, yes, much better.—(to MADELINE) Receive my best compliments, Madame—you are really more than beautiful.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Monsieur—(almost betraying herself) William!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (interrupting her) Madame (aside, kissing her hand) Oh, you should be happy, Madame, surrounded by riches, luxury—you should not hesitate between so noble a family, and that of a wretched wanderer, a mountebank.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Oblige me, Chevalier, by stating the mission with which you were charged to this man—the offers made by me, and the way in which they were received by him.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ah, she wishes to know—I'll tell her—Imagine my offering him gold, which he indignantly refused, and the more I offered, the more strongly he refused, rejected, " It is my wife," said he " it' my child, I want them, and not your paltry coin;" so finding him so stupidly obstinate, we had him seized, pitched him into a coach drove him off, and threw him on board a vessel, the captain of which we had previously paid to bear him away.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (aside) Oh, 'tis horrible.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: From that day we have seen him but once, and he again asked where his wife was. There was a struggle between us, but that struggle was not for long.(with marked accent.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (as if prompting him) Oblige me by repeating to her that which you stated to me in your letters—that since his separation from her, his life has been a scandal, his days and nights spent in disorder and dissipation.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I wrote that to you did I?(strikes his pocket, where he indicates ROLLAC'S paper are) quite true.(aside) I have the villain's letter here—quite true—you may suppose, Madame, his cheeks are pale, his eyes swollen, his existence misery, his heart broken by a cruel separation from a wife and child, on whom that heart doated, but you may be mistaken—the Chevalier de Rollac assures you that you are forgotten by Belphégor, whose days and nights are spent in degrading forgetfulness, and mad hilarity.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: You hinted, too, he was ever at the low gaming house, ever in the tavern.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (with bitterness) The tavern—yes, yes, you well know Madame that drink was his only joy, all his love, his very life. The tavern, oh, yes—when you fled, drink became his hourly habit, he was seen in every quarter, street, lane, seeking his family, watching for them at each house, scanning each window; one day he saw the face of a fair and sickly child peeping from a silk-curtained window, " Ah," cried he, " 'tis my Jeanne, my loved one." He rushed past each lackey, bounded each stair, entered each room, found, clasped, the child in his arms, she cried(imitates the small cry of a child) and 'twas but that cry told him his heart had deceived him; he was about to depart—but, overpowered, they dragged him to the Prefecture for robbery, attempting to steal the child. Singular, was it not, quite amusing was it not, Messieurs? Ha, ha,ha! But you don't laugh, you'll laugh, Madame, I am sure.(crosses to them, and then to her.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (L buries her face in her hands) Oh, fearful, horrible recital.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Chevalier, here is a letter I have addressed to the King, in my own name and yours, which, as the friend and executor of my son, you will oblige me by signing.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (reading.) To beg him to empower me to seize and force this Belphégor on board a vessel, never to return; and also, that Madeline, in the meantime, be duly authorised to pass in the eyes of the world as the widow of a German officer, who died in the service of his Majesty.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Will you sign, Chevalier?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: No—no—no!(as endeavouring to make him hear.) Oh! 'tis fearful.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You are a widow, Madame—Belphégor is dead to you; gone to die in a far off land—unmourned, perhaps—when dead, ungraved! Poor Belphégor, go! Heaven may have more pity towards you than a bitter world!

sp.speaker: JUDGE.
sp.p: What! pity on such a fellow?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (angrily.) Sir!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: He is right; what pity should such vermin have from Heaven or man!(goes up towards D U K E . )

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (as fatigued at argument, gives the pen.) Will you sign?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What? sign for the separation of two hearts knit in fond and fervent love—hands, too, joined in Heaven's name? No, proud Duke, I'll not!(tears or breaks up the pen and casts it on the table before him.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (in great rage, C.) Ha! know you, Sir, it is to the Duke de Montbazon you speak?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (L., aside.) Oh, Heaven guard him!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (with a loud laugh.) Ha, ha, ha! they know not, (these idiot fashion's fools), they guess not, although they see my almost suffocating rage, hear my wild laugh, drowned in the tears they've wrung, and yet they guess not, know not!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (by table.) Ha! you are then ——

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (throwing off his wig.) I am—I am Belphégor!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Belphégor!(Tableau.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, the mountebank—the miserable, degraded wretch— the brute—but this brute has a wife—children—and comes here to redeem them all! Do you hear me, thieves?(all make a movement of indignation towards him.) Ah! take care—the mountebank may make them laugh upon the public square, but he can here bring tears.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: You menace!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And if I do, what then?(with a proud, threatening look at him and all.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: William—husband—here me!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I hear nothing—I am your husband, your master. The law! there is a law above yours, Messieurs, under that law's sacred power this is my wife; and I'll take her in spite of you.(to MADELINE) Madame, I go with you to Jeanne, my child, the child you stole from me.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (approaching) Stole—oh, husband! that child was dying.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, dying! I knew not.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: 'T i s true, I was told of but one resource to save her—to that I flew—assured I had no other hope of life for her—I quitted you—bore her from you, but to preserve her, as I have soul or hope!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: She is here.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Let me see her—embrace her.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Come—come.(as they go up) A SERVANT enters.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The substitute of the Procureur of the King. Enter DE COURGEMONT, and GUARDS.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: It means this, Duke, that a man has introduced himself here under the false name of Rollac.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What says he?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Oh, William, William!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: And that we are officially informed that man is no other than Lavarennes.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Him—him, Lavarennes!(with satisfaction.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (by} DUKE. R.H.) No, no, 'tis false, 'tis malice, he ——

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: I arrest you in the King's name!(they arrest him.) Guards cross round in front of him, as he is dragged up.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Madeline—my child—my child, let me but see and embrace my child.(as they drag him away.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: William!(flying after him.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (detaining her.) Silence, in respect for me, in pity for him.

div.stage: MADELINE sinks as overpowered, they drag BELPHEGOR off as the scene closes—COMMANDER, R., JUDGE, L.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: —Apartment in the Hotel of FLORA NINA, near the Citadel of Blaye.
Enter FLORA NINA, with HENRI, (dressed neatly)} R.

sp.speaker: HENRI.
sp.p: ( R . ) Oh, pray, Madame, do take me to my father.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (C.) I will, my dear; but you know, when your father and yourself arrived here three days since, you were both in great distress.

sp.speaker: HENRI.
sp.p: Oh. yes, indeed we were, which you kindly relieved.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
HENRI.
sp.p: I hope he killed the villain! I would have done it, for his taking mother from us.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Your father feared he might be arrested, and fled—but first begged me to take care of his child for a few days, until he could return with safety, which I have done.

sp.speaker: HENRI.
sp.p: Oh yes, and kindly; but you are not my mother(weeps.)

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Dear boy, you shall see her shortly. I have heard of your father; go, get you ready, and I'll take you to him.(puts him L . H . )

sp.speaker: HENRI.
sp.p: Thanks—thanks! (she kisses him.) Enter HERCULES, L.—sees FLORA and HENRI—he starts, and HENRI goes off, R.1 E.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Ha! I've caught you, have I?(in great passion.)

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (R.C.) Caught me?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: That boy?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Well, what of him?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Ah! that's what I want to know. I heard of him yesterday—to-day, I have seen him. The little scoundrel!

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Scoundrel, Sir?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: (making a horrible face) Oh, Flora, Nina Flora, here have I been for the last four months adoring you as fast as I could find strength; and, just as I am on the tip-top of the Parnassus of happiness, I find you with a thumping boy to your back, half as big as myself.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: It may be well, Sir—but it is not well, Madame. What do you think of that boy?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Much more than I do of you—but that boy is not mine.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Oh, ah, yes—I see—the old tale(mysteriously). If he's not your boy, what does the boy here?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (in the same tone) What's that to you?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: What's that to me! Suppose I was your husband?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: I cannot suppose that which can never be.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Not be—not be! No, not under these circumstances.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Nor any other.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Do you tell me you don't love me?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Do you think I'm out of my mind?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: How dare you let me fall in love with you, then?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: How could I help your making yourself a fool?

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Madame, I never made myself a fool.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: No, you were a fool, ready-made.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: Do you know the consequence of such language to a man of noble blood?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Noble fiddlestick!

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: That's enough!—after the fiddlestick, I've done(buttons his coat, and slaps his hat upon his head).} Know, Madame, I did intend to honour you with my person, name, and fortune!

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Your name I laugh at—your person I reject—and your fortune I would not pick up !

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p: What did you persuade me to run away with you for?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: To teaze your stiff-starched old grand aunt, annoy your stupidly proud family, and amuse myself at their expense. Adieu, adieu, most noble and high-blooded Hercules. Ha, ha, ha! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: HER.
sp.p:
Oh, oh, oh, my heart, it feels so weak, dear me, I'm quite
staggered; and this girl's behaviour, really, oh, bless me, I'm afraid I'm going to lose my senses. If my grand aunt did but know how I've been treated, oh(nearly falls) my knees are as weak as my head.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: —The Platform of the Citadel of Blaye, various Entrances from the Citadel, and high ramparts—Two Sentinels discovered on duty at back—Music.
Enter DE COURGEMONT, R.U.E., with Guards, who pass at back.}

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Tell the Provost Marshal that I am here. (then to himself) I have luckily had good guards placed over this shabby red-bearded fellow—he is here. Enter ROLLAC, L. 3 E., he wears a disguise. —Approach.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: (aside) Now, for a high tone.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Now, Sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: (L.C.) This is fine treatment to a man who has been useful to you, and may be so again.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (R.C.) You certainly pretend that you sent the letter which enabled us to arrest Lavarennes this morning.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Quite true. I'll tell you the contents of the letter:—"I write this to inform you that Lavarennes is disguised, and passing under the name of Rollac; and that he will present himself this morning at the residence of the Duke de Montbazon; he has also passed for a long time as the mountebank Belphégor;" I told you where he had passed the sight, and where you would find the rags he cast off, to take the dress of a man of fashion. You see the service I have rendered you, and, in common gratitude, you should reward me as a friend, not imprison me as a felon.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: On the contrary, if all this is true, I'll give you your liberty, you shall remain in my especial service. Go—they are conducting the prisoner to this spot—his fate will be at once decided.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: I submit.(aside.) They'll not dream of seeking me in this place, that's one comfort. Exit L. 3 E. Enter BELPHEGOR, guarded, L. H. 2 E.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Take him to the judges.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: One word, Monsieur; I hear they talk of shooting me—I want to know for what ?

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Are you not Lavarennes?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Lavarennes? I tell you I am not!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: I say you are, or the Chevalier Rollac.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Guilliame, then.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Ah ! Belphégor—the mountebank!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, true enough.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: I know;—William—Belphégor—Rollac — Lavarennes— mountebank—vagabond—traitor—thief—assassin—you shall be shot!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh! I see you are convinced; so are the ministers and judges—wise judges, you all are, to know a man's name better than he does himself. Enter FLORA NINA, L. 3 E.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: I would speak to the substitute. COUR What do you want with him, Madame?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (C. sees BELPHEGOR) 'Tis he!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Of course it is; I am he!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (L.) If I am not deceived—no—no!

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Why, bless me, it's the pretty dancer! I had quite forgotten my office. What have you to say, Mademoiselle?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: I merely have to request permission to deliver a letter to the governor, for a friend.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Ah, I see! (takes the letter, about to read.)

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (aside to} BELPHEGOR) A word—you remember me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) Yes, yes—my boy—my Henri!

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: He is safe; it is for him that I have come for you.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (looking and twisting letter) What writing! " My dear substitute!"

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tell me—where is he? Let me see him—embrace him.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Be firm—you shall—he is safe!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! I guess, you have seen his mother?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And she?

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (closing the letter) This letter requests that you may be allowed to speak to a prisoner.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: It does. Chevalier

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Sorry to refuse, but I am compelled. Prisoners are allowed to converse with no one.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: But I want to inform him a lady will shortly be here.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) My wife—she's coming.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: It's impossible: she can have no business here.

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: Yes; to save this prisoner.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aside) Ah! she can save me—she will.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Save—ridiculous!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Save—oh, thanks, Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Why, do you know that this is the man, and he has heard every word?

sp.speaker: FLORA.
sp.p: (laughing, aside) Adieu, Monsieur. Of course, if you won't let me speak to him, I can't tell him what I came to say.(she curtsies, and goes off L. 3 E.)

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: It's my firm opinion, she would humbug me if she could. Conduct your prisoner

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
She—Madeline—will come, and I have nothing to fear. Exit, guarded, R.H. 3 E
Enter DUKE and DE BLANGY, R.U.E.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: Now, Duke, we are alone, and moments are precious. I tell you that this man is not Lavarennes.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R.C.) I know it, cousin.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: (L.C.) I have seen this Lavarennes, under the name of Rollac.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: I know all you would say; and have in my possession this man's pardon—but he shall not possess it, unless he consent to leave France for ever.

sp.speaker: BLAN.
sp.p: I am charged with this message from her:—" That she insists on being confronted with him." What answer give you to this? She comes. MADELINE appears up steps, R.H.U.E.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (after a moment) Tell the judges she is ready to appear. Exit BLANGY, R. 3 E.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (advances) Duke.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R.C.) What brought you here?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (L.C.) A sacred duty, the accomplishment of which nothing shall prevent—I have sworn it, Duke.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: You own, this man for twelve years has been called Belphégor, and 'tis proved that for twenty years he's not been called Lavarennes.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: I said that I had lived under his roof, that I had shared his misery, that I had witnessed his poverty, his misfortune, and suffering—but that I never knew him commit one single act at which the proudest might blush; he is not the man you say—he is no thief, no villain!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: It is in seeking to save, that you destroy him, for I have here his pardon.(shows it.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: His pardon?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Which he shall have, at the price of your silence; and if one word of yours avows him to be Belphégor, he is lost!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Do you mean this ?

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (holding pardon) I do. If but one word fall from your lips, acknowledging him your husband, he is doomed. This pardon, obtained by my interest, is destroyed, and no power shall save him.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: And you ask me, even in his very presence, to deny, to renounce my husband.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: I am the guardian of my house's honour, I am the parent of your father, the preserver of your child, and tell you solemnly that on your lips depend his pardon or his death. Enter COURGEMONT, JAILOR, two JUDGES of the Court, MARSHAL, GUARDS, SOLDIERS, GENDARMES, R. 3 E.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (crosses to L.) He is here.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (R.C., aside) Oh, brain. BELPHEGOR is brought on, R. 3 E.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: My daughter, Messieurs.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (C.) Madame—approach, Lavarennes.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (R.C., seeing her) 'Tis she, and I am safe.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: You will please, Madame, to reply to my questions.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She will do so, and to your confusion.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (C.) Madame, oblige me by casting your eyes around.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (hesitating) Ye—yes, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Now, say—do you know this man?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Speak, Madeline, and fear not.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (aside to her) Remember that his life is in your hands. (about to tear pardon.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (after an effort, looks at BELPHEGOR) I—I know him not.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (staggered) You do not know me?

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (signing to take him away) Guards, do your duty.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (disengages himself, and springs towards MADELINE) Madeline, do I dream this—look up—look on me, then say you know me not.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (L.C.) Heaven have pity upon me and him.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (C.) And you hear, Messieurs, this man dares to pretend (turns towards the D U K E ) that this lady is his wife, and the mother of his two children.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes; of children, given to me by heaven at her hands—that she, with me, have taught to lisp each night the prayer of childhood and bless us both as father!—mother!—that have pillowed on our arms, in sweet and slumbering innocence—that she has loved with all a mother's love.—(seeing her failing) Ha! speak—speak!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: ( L . ) Madeline! (about to tear the pardon.)

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (L.C.) That man is not my husband.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (aghast) I'll ask no more if you are my wife—but I demand of you, are you not the mother of our children? Enter FLORA and HENRI, U.E.R.H. — Answer, Madame, do you know this child? ( H E N R I , C.)

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: (runs to her) Mother, my dear mother, have I again found you? Oh, embrace me!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (to DUKE.) It is my son—my son! My heart will surely break.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (to MADELINE) Look—behold that child—speak but a word to save you from lasting, from eternal shame.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (sees the DUKE with the paper) Ah! (trembling.)

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: Mother, mother!—Oh, why do you not answer?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Leave me—you are deceived—I—I am not your mother!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (C.) Oh! (clasps his hands, with an inward groan.)

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: Father, father—what says she ?(crosses to him, R.H.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She says thou art not her child, boy. Well, think no more of this woman—we must forget her, as she has forgotten us.

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: (kneeling, and taking MADELINE'S hand) Mother, is this true —that I am not your child?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (the DUKE looks upon her) Oh, pity!—mercy!—my strength is gone. (to the DUKE, he again offers to destroy the paper) No, no—I have spoken—you are not my child!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
It is not in nature—and all nature must have flown from
out her heart and breast. (aside) Well, well, I'll not wait for their fire to reach my heart, No, you shall see me perish before your eyes!(he makes a bound towards the parapet of the platform,) Madeline you have denied, abandoned me. I have now neither happiness nor hope, there is no future for me, that I should live for; and from this rampart I pass to a world where poverty is not punished as the worst of crimes—farewell (is about to throw himself from the ramparts, when MADELINE screams.)

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: (runs up, C.) Father—father!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (by DUKE, L.C.) Great heavens, hold! for your children's sake—hold!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Speak—say—are they mine and yours? D U K E . Madeline!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Away—leave me(runs to BELPHEGOR.) Yes, yes, his children are mine. I am—I am his wife.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (jumps from rampart and kneels to her.) Ha, Madeline, be thou blessed!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (runs to D U K E ) Father—Duke—dare you destroy that pardon!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (to COURGEMONT) You see now, most sapient magistrate, that the lady is my wife—the mother of my two children.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (R.C.) But 'tis still for the Court to decide if you are to be shot, or not.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Oh—in mercy!

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (crosses to COURGEMONT) Stay, Sir, will you oblige me by retiring for a short time, I would speak in private with this man. (they bow and retire, R. AND L. 3 E.) BELPHEGOR takes FLORA'S hand, who goes with MADELINE, L. 3 E.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R.C.) Madeline has proclaimed you as her husband; but to the eyes of your judges, you are still Lavarennes, the presumptive proofs are too strong. Your death would save the honour of my house; but, notwithstanding this, you shall live—here is your pardon.(gives pardon.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (L.C.) I thank your Grace, I thought you'd not allow them to assassinate me, when you knew this to be my wife.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: Your wife—see her united to a man who has lived as a mendicant upon the public streets! no—there is your pardon, but you must go—to exile—to oblivion.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis of little import to me—you keep your pride; but I take my wife and children. Enter MADELINE, L. 3 E. coming between them quickly with HENRI and JEANNE.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: (C.) William, here is your daughter, your little Jeanne.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (C.) My little lost one—my own dove—ah! that face, too, in bloom of health—yes—yes, restored safe—for this my thankful tears.(on his knees.)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: ( R . ) Look on your child—health beaming in her face, and in her eye.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (caressing her) My beautiful.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: She shall be happy, give her to me, she shall be as my daughter—what do you reply?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My eyes are open now—my poor children, I must not love you in selfishness, but as a father(rises); her now bright eyes and health-tinted cheeks, inform me so. Give me your oath, you will rear this boy also in honour and respect.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: I swear it.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You'll love him as you love my—your pretty Jeanne.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: He shall be my son, as Jeanne is my daughter.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I believe you(takes the DUKE apart). You can now, Monsieur, break my marriage, you shall never see me more. I bear myself away, where you will—'tis the same to me—to Cayenne, as this pardon insists. I will swear, in my turn, never to behold my wife or children again(struggling with his feelings)—pardon these tears; but I am still a man, though a despised one. Suffer me to embrace them (with choked utterance) for the last time—adieu, Henri, adieu—when you are happy, sometimes think of me, Jeanne (embraces her). Farewell, Madeline! pardon what you have suffered for me, it is my misery, not my sin, that I am poor—I loved you—shall love you ever—adieu!

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: No—no, I will not part with you, I will not suffer you to depart alone, where you go, so do I.(goes up C. to him)

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: It means, Duke, that I am not alone a mother—I am a wife. By your protection my children may be led to happiness and honour; but from him, my husband(goes to him) I part not.

sp.speaker: HEN.
sp.p: (running to them—dragging his sister L.C.) Father—mother, do not leave us, if you go, pray—pray, take us with you?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: My children!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ah ! you see, Duke—we cannot part, you see.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: (R.H., embraces Children) Oh, childhood! thy voice pleads strongly: and, casting pride aside, I yield to its holy impulse. The trial has been severe, but your mutual love will be the dearer for its tested faith. Belphégor, it was to save thy life I forced denial of thee from her lips. I shall now be alone. I would have saved our house's honours in our house's blood—therefore, sought thy child—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Duke—when a mother's reason, when her heart, can bear the parting, they shall be rendered to you. Madeline, you'll bring your mind to bear their loss.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Yes, in time—their loss, not yours.(embracing.) COURGEMENT and the rest re-enter.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Duke, the Court awaits you.

sp.speaker: DUKE.
sp.p: It is useless—this man is pardoned.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: Lavarennes pardoned! ROLLAC enters, L. 3 E.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: Oh, oh! I am happy to hear it—Lavarennes pardoned! Monsieur, I'll thank you for my passport to Portugal.(taking off his wig and false whiskers.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: He!—this man, Rollac!

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: No, my good fellow—I am Lavarennes—I am saved! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (gives paper to CORGEMONT .) Read this, Sir.

sp.speaker: COUR.
sp.p: (R. reads) Saved from being shot, but not from transportation to Cayenne.

sp.speaker: ROL.
sp.p: The devil!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: ( L . H . ) Don't be in a hurry for that gentleman—he'll wait on you quite soon enough. Exit ROLLAC, guarded, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: ( L . C . ) Thus, William, pride ever sinks before truth's radiant eye !

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And man, whatever his chance of birth, may still be happy in his heart's affection, so that that heart be true to honour and itself.
